shredder 0.1.0

Working With brms

Source: vignettes/brms.Rmd
brms.Rmd
library(shredder)
library(brms)

Generate Data

group <- rep(c("treat", "placebo"), 
             each = 30)

symptom_post <- c(
  rnorm(30, mean = 1, sd = 2), 
  rnorm(30, mean = 0, sd = 1)
)

dat1 <- data.frame(group, symptom_post)

Run Model

fit <- brm(bf(symptom_post ~ group, sigma ~ group), 
           data = dat1, 
           family = gaussian())
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 2000; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 4000

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept         0.20974   0.18734 -0.16995  0.58045       4871 1.00014
sigma_Intercept  -0.01457   0.12937 -0.25371  0.25910       3443 0.99990
grouptreat        1.14936   0.43732  0.30668  2.04215       2412 0.99968
sigma_grouptreat  0.77187   0.18551  0.40895  1.14763       3671 1.00025

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Select first 100 Posterior Samples from each Chain

fit_slice <- fit%>%stan_slice(1:100)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1100; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 400

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept         0.20603   0.18938 -0.17229  0.55380        404 1.00237
sigma_Intercept  -0.01765   0.13205 -0.27242  0.26834        267 1.01300
grouptreat        1.17670   0.43148  0.39742  2.03250        286 0.99335
sigma_grouptreat  0.76882   0.19112  0.39986  1.19404        333 0.99934

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_slice%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Sample 25% of Posterior Samples from each Chain

fit_sample <- fit%>%
  stan_sample_frac(0.25)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1250; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 1000

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept         0.21199   0.18481 -0.15830  0.58403        943 0.99885
sigma_Intercept  -0.01226   0.13123 -0.25055  0.25416        875 0.99996
grouptreat        1.14002   0.42701  0.31862  1.98439       1056 0.99911
sigma_grouptreat  0.77015   0.18437  0.41410  1.13719        957 0.99954

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_sample%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Filter Posterior Samples by Conditional

fit_filter <- fit%>%
  stan_filter(b_grouptreat>=2)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1038; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 152

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept         0.13661   0.21084 -0.24887  0.53063         23 1.11967
sigma_Intercept   0.00146   0.14427 -0.29134  0.26837        171 0.98707
grouptreat        1.43811   0.58138  0.37853  2.33503          4 1.49889
sigma_grouptreat  0.76933   0.20225  0.43258  1.21535        164 0.98340

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_filter%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Filter Posterior Samples by Conditional Subset Chain

fit_filter_chain <- fit%>%
  stan_filter(b_grouptreat>=2)%>%
  stan_keep(chains = 1)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 1 chains, each with iter = 1038; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 38

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept        -0.01059   0.18756 -0.36581  0.30468         31 0.98812
sigma_Intercept   0.02132   0.15600 -0.34953  0.21698         41 0.98238
grouptreat        2.16330   0.13252  2.00818  2.48511         36 0.98212
sigma_grouptreat  0.79642   0.18198  0.48437  1.23424         42 1.00071

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
